content: The "Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2010" is the short title of this Act. It focuses on bullying and harassment prevention policies, programs, and statistics. The Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2010 amends reporting requirements to include bullying and harassment under the Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act. It also updates state application criteria to include the incidence of bullying and harassment incidents and student perceptions of their school environment. The Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2010 amends reporting requirements to address bullying and harassment in schools. It includes provisions for state educational agencies to assist districts in preventing and responding to such incidents. The Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2010 is amended to include performance indicators for bullying and harassment prevention programs and activities. Additionally, there is a requirement for annual notice to parents and students describing prohibited conduct in discipline policies. The Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2010 is amended to include grievance procedures for complaints regarding prohibited conduct in discipline policies, specifying responsible officials and resolution timelines. The Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2010 is amended to include teaching students about the consequences of bullying and harassment, as well as implementing programs to address the causes of bullying and harassment and training school personnel on prevention and intervention strategies. The Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2010 is amended to include reporting and impact evaluation related to bullying and harassment, as well as defining bullying and harassment as part of drug and violence prevention efforts. The definition of bullying and harassment is now part of drug and violence prevention efforts. The term 'bullying' refers to conduct that adversely affects a student's ability to participate in school activities by causing fear of physical harm, based on factors such as race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, or religion. The term 'harassment' refers to conduct that adversely affects a student's ability to participate in school activities or benefit from educational programs. It includes association with a person or group with certain characteristics defined by a State or local educational agency.
